title: Best power meter pedals 2025
content:
Cyclist
Best power meter pedals 2025

For many cyclists, a power meter is an essential supplement to their riding, offering power data on their cycling computer while riding, as well as for post-ride analysis to track their performance and trends in their fitness.

While many of the best road bikes are now sold with a crankset power meter pre-installed, pedal power meters have the advantage of easy portability between bikes, while still offering accurate power measurement.

Older models often needed precise tightening using a torque wrench and in some cases accurate alignment on the cranks to provide an accurate reading, but newer pedal power meters can be set up without. They usually feature auto-calibration as well.

Pedal power meters are now available for all the major pedal systems with the exception of Time, but including Look Keo and Shimano SPD-SL for road use as well as Shimano SPD for off-road or all-road use.

In many cases, you can choose between the same power meter model with single sided or dual-sided measurement. While single sided power meters are cheaper, you won’t get left/right balance data, which can be useful if your pedalling is asymmetric. Dual measurement will provide a more accurate measurement though, as a single sided power meter just doubles the reading from one pedal.

All the pedal power meters below broadcast over both ANT+ and BLE, so compatibility with a bike computer won’t be an issue, although you may get extra data when using the ANT+ protocol.

We’ve rounded up the best power meter pedals below, along with stats on their pedal system compatibility, options and claimed accuracy.

The best power meters pedals at a glance

Below are the currently available pedal power meters, with prices for single sided (SS) and dual sided (DS) options.

  1. Favero Assioma: RRP SS £475 / DS £720
  2. Favero Assioma Shi spindles: RRP DS £575
  3. Favero Assioma Pro MX: RRP SS £480 / DS £720
  4. Garmin Rally RK/RS: RRP SS £429.99 / DS £769.99
  5. Garmin Rally XC: RRP SS £469.99 / DS £859.99
  6. Look Keo Blade: RRP SS £600 / DS £900
  7. Look X-Track: RRP SS £675 / DS £1,000
  8. SRM X-Power MTB: RRP SS €839.50 / DS €1,427.74
  9. SRM X-Power Road: RRP SS €839.50 / DS €1,427.74
  10. Wahoo Speedplay Power: RRP SS £549.99 / DS £849.99

Why trust Cyclist’s advice?

Alongside our reviews of bikes, we follow closely the developments in cycling tech here at Cyclist, with comprehensive coverage of new product launches as well as detailed reviews of products including power meters both online and in Cyclist magazine. That places us in a great position to highlight all the best pedal based power meter options available, along with their specs and pros and cons.

We’re not paid for product placements or recommendations, so you can trust Cyclist to provide unbiased guidance.

Best power meter pedals

Favero Assioma

RRP SS £475 / DS £720 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Look Keo
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 152g
  • Claimed battery life: 50 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 54mm
  • Pedal stack height: 10.5mm
  • Waterproof rating: IP67

The Favero Assioma power meter pedals are made in Italy and are compatible with Look road cleats. The electronics are housed in a pod inboard on the spindle and there’s a rechargeable battery with a Micro-USB charge port. Favero claims that its pedals can provide a wide range of metrics, including where pressure is applied across the pedal platform and even time spent seated versus out of saddle.

There’s an upgrade kit available if you want to convert from single sided to dual sided measurement post-purchase.

  • Read our full Favero Assioma power meter review
  • Buy dual sided power meter now from Amazon (£658.99)

Favero Assioma Shi spindles

RRP DS £575 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD-SL
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 99g (plus pedal body)
  • Claimed battery life: 50 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 64/65mm
  • Pedal stack height: Pedal body dependent
  • Waterproof rating: IP67

Favero doesn’t sell complete Shimano SPD-SL power meter pedals, instead offering dual sided only instrumented spindles that can be used to mount a Shimano pedal body. You can choose from a range of SPD-SL pedals from Dura-Ace down to Shimano’s entry-level 540 resin pedals. Favero quotes a weight of 157g with Dura-Ace R8000 pedal bodies.

Favero’s Q Factor is wider with Shimano than with Look, which may be an advantage for some riders, avoiding the need for pedal spindle extenders if their bike fit recommends a wider stance width. You get the same set of power and other stats as with the Look-compatible pedals.

  • Read our full Favero Assioma Shi power meter review
  • Buy now from Bikeinn (£496.99)

Favero Assioma Pro MX

RRP SS £480 / DS £720 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 191g
  • Claimed battery life: 60 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 11.2mm
  • Waterproof rating: IP67

Favero also offers an SPD-compatible off-road pedal in both single sided and dual sided versions. Unlike the road pedals, the sensors and battery are fully enclosed in the pedal spindle, lessening the likelihood of damage when riding off-road. The battery is recharged with a clip-on connector and provides a claimed 60 hour life.

Favero provides auto calibration and the same stats as with its road pedals, including its standing/sitting and platform centre offset data. You can buy a separate upgrade kit to add a second instrumented pedal if you’ve started with the single sided option, as with the Assioma road pedals.

  • Buy now dual sided from Bikeinn (£658.49)

Garmin Rally RK/RS

RRP SS £429.99 / DS £769.99 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Look Keo/Shimano SPD-SL
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 160g
  • Claimed battery life: 120 hours
  • Battery type: LR44 coin cell
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 12.2mm
  • Waterproof rating: IPX7

Garmin sells both single sided and dual measuring power meter pedals, with both Look and Shimano three-bolt compatible options in its Rally series. There’s also an upgrade instrumented pedal if you choose a single sided meter and subsequently decide to upgrade to dual sided. As well as power, you get data such as pedalling efficiency and smoothness and seated vs standing time.

Garmin also sells pedal bodies, so you can swap between Shimano and Look road systems, as well as its SPD off-road pedal bodies, as below. Garmin’s electronics are fully enclosed in the pedal spindle. It does use a coin cell rather than a rechargeable battery though, so you need to unscrew a battery cover at the end of the spindle when your battery needs replacing at the end of the 120 hours claimed battery life.

  • Buy now dual sided from Tredz (£719.99)

Garmin Rally XC

RRP SS £469.99 / DS £859.99 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 222g
  • Claimed battery life: 120 hours
  • Battery type: LR44 coin cell
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 13.5mm
  • Waterproof rating: IPX7

The Garmin Rally XC pedals are designed for off-road use, with an SPD-compatible pedal body that sits on a pedal spindle that can be converted to use with SPD-SL or Look Keo cleats, with the purchase of the appropriate Garmin pedal body. There’s the same range of stats as for the road pedals, as well as the same coin cell battery with a claimed 120 hour lifespan.

Garmin charges a little more for the Rally XC than the road cleat compatible pedals and, as with them, there’s the option to change from single sided to dual sided measurement as an upgrade.

  • Buy now dual sided from Tredz (£809.99)

Look Keo Blade Power

RRP SS £600 / DS £900 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Look Keo
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 130g
  • Claimed battery life: 60 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 10.8mm
  • Waterproof rating: IPX7

Look’s road pedal power meter is compatible with its Keo road system. It has a carbon body and carbon blade cleat retainer and latest pedal body shape, which Look claims is more aero. The pedal stack height is identical to the non-instrumented Keo Blade pedals at 10.8mm and all the electronics are enclosed in the pedal spindle, including a rechargeable battery with a claimed 60 hour runtime between charges.

Look sells both single sided and dual sided power meters, as well as instrumented spindles and replacement pedal bodies. You can purchase carbon blades separately with 12Nm, 16Nm or 20Nm retention to fine-tune your release tension.

  • Buy now dual sided from Bikeinn (£755.99)

Look X-Track Power

RRP SS £675 / DS £1,000 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 202g
  • Claimed battery life: 60 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 10.7mm
  • Waterproof rating: IP67

Look also sells the SPD-compatible X-Track power meter in dual sided and single sided variants. The X-Track Power pedals use the same spindle as the Keo Power pedals, with X-Track metal pedal bodies made from recycled aluminium. They have the same stack height as the non-instrumented X-Track pedals and offer the usual range of pedalling stats, in addition to power measurement.

  • Buy now dual sided from Winstanley’s Bikes (£899.99)

SRM X-Power MTB

RRP SS €839.50 / DS €1,427.74 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-2%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 194g
  • Claimed battery life: 30 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 54mm
  • Pedal stack height: 10.5mm
  • Waterproof rating: Not specified

SRM was the originator of the cycling power meter and still sells crankset power meters, as well as branching out into pedal power meters for road and off-road use. It offers single sided and dual measuring options with long and short spindles to suit different crank thicknesses and an upgrade kit to convert from single to dual measurement. While other brands’ pedal power meters come in a single colour, you can choose between seven colours.

It’s another system with the electronics housed in the pedal spindle, with a rechargeable battery offering a 30 hour claimed runtime. Uniquely, SRM also offers a flat pedal power meter at the same price in single and dual measurement versions and with a claimed weight of 205g per pedal.

  • Buy now dual sided from SRM (€1,427.74 plus VAT & shipping)

SRM X-Power Road

RRP SS €839.50 / DS €1,427.74 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Shimano SPD-SL
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-2%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 140g
  • Claimed battery life: 30 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 53mm
  • Pedal stack height: 9.8mm
  • Waterproof rating: Not specified

SRM’s road pedal power meter is compatible with Shimano SPD-SL cleats and boasts a low stack height of just 9.8mm. As with the MTB version, SRM sells short and long spindle pedals with single and dual sided measurement, although there are just three colours to choose from: black, blue and red.

  • Buy now dual sided from SRM (€1,427.74 plus VAT & shipping)

Wahoo Speedplay Power

RRP SS £549.99 / DS £849.99 | View offer

  • Compatibility: Speedplay
  • Claimed accuracy: +/-1%
  • Claimed weight per instrumented pedal: 138g
  • Claimed battery life: 75 hours
  • Battery type: Rechargeable Li ion
  • Q Factor: 55mm
  • Pedal stack height: 13.0mm
  • Waterproof rating: Not specified

If you use the Speedplay pedal system, there’s only one power meter option available, with Wahoo selling its Speedplay-compatible power meter in single sided and dual sensing options. The stack height is a little higher than standard Speedplay pedals and the electronics are housed in a pod on the pedal spindle, with enclosed LED indicators for battery and pairing status.

Although the pedal weight looks lower than the competition, bear in mind that Speedplay’s metal cleats are significantly heavier than those of competing systems. The pedals are compatible with both the Speedplay standard tension and easy tension cleats and Wahoo claims a 75 hour life from its rechargeable battery.

  • Buy now dual sided from Condor Cycles (£849.99)

author: Pnorman
